titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Pauli Murray Project Records, 2004-2012 RL.11019
titlestmt.author: Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-07-29 20:26:48 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies

did.abstract: The Pauli Murray Project is an ongoing project in the Duke Human Rights Center at the Franklin Humanities Institute. It sponsors programs and courses creating documentaries and other community resources about Durham history. The Pauli Murray Project Records include both community projects and oral history projects from undergraduate courses offered by Duke University through the Center for Documentary Studies and the Franklin Humanities Institute.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research, but original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use. Please contact the Rubenstein Library in advance of your visit to request the production of listening or viewing copies.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48-hours to retrieve these materials for research use.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into series: Community Projects, Oral History Projects, and Audiovisual/Electronic Media.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Pauli Murray Project is an ongoing project in the Duke Human Rights Center at the Franklin Humanities Institute. It sponsors programs and courses creating documentaries and other community resources about Durham history.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Pauli Murray Project Records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2013.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Pauli Murray Project Records, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this finding aid: 2013-0136

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Pauli Murray Project Records include both community projects and oral history projects from undergraduate courses offered by Duke University through the Center for Documentary Studies and the Franklin Humanities Institute. Contents include various projects documenting Parrish Street/Black Wall Street in Durham, mapping and documenting civil rights/human rights in Durham, the Still Walking for Justice march, and a Brown vs. Board of Education anniversary exhibit. Files are typically arranged by undergraduate student name, and often included audiovisual recordings of oral history interviews conducted as part of a course assignment. Consult the collection guide for more information. All audiovisual materials have been removed to Box 4.

controlaccess.subject: Civil rights -- North Carolina -- Durham
controlaccess.corpname: Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual and electronic records have been removed to the Audiovisual/Electronic Media Series. These items are closed to use. Please contact the Rubenstein Library in advance of your visit to request the production of listening or viewing copies.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
